articles.title: Mommy, Do You Like Being a Mom?

content.headline: Responding Honestly When Your Child Asks If You Like Motherhood
content.intro: When a child asks “Mommy, do you like being a mom?”, it’s more than a casual question—it touches on your identity, your joy, your struggle and your calling in one simple phrase.

sections.title: A Loaded Question
sections.content: The author recalls how her eight-year-old daughter asked her whether she enjoys being a mom, and how that simple question carried weight because motherhood is about more than daily duties.
points: It’s not just a job—it’s a calling that shapes a child’s view of you.
When you answer, you are communicating how you feel about yourself and your role.
Children absorb your truths: both the joys you express and the burdens you bear.

sections.title: Principle 1: Love Your Child
sections.content: Regardless of how you feel about certain parts of motherhood, scripture tells us to love our children deeply. The author points to Matthew 22:39 and Titus 2:4 as foundations for this love.
points: Loving your child does not depend on whether you like every moment of motherhood.
Your child needs to feel valued, cherished and safe in your care.
Distinct between the hard parts of the role and your abiding relationship with your child.

sections.title: Principle 2: Teach Them Diligently
sections.content: Using Deuteronomy 6:7, the author encourages mothers to teach God’s commands carefully and consistently in everyday life—through breakfast, drives, bedtime.
points: Make spiritual conversations normal in your home life.
Use moments of routine (car rides, meals) as teaching opportunities.
Even when things are hard, model and invite your child into faith.

sections.title: Principle 3: Tell the Stories
sections.content: The author shares a personal story of her own youth (with a back-brace) and how her mother turned her challenges into testimony. This shows the power of story to shape children’s understanding of God’s faithfulness.
points: Memories of God’s faithfulness anchor children’s faith.
Tell both the joys and the sorrows—authentic stories matter.
Lead your child to see God’s work, not just your efforts.

sections.title: Depend on the Lord
sections.content: Parenting is ultimately an act of faith. The author returns to James 1:5 and reminds readers that when they are unsure how to answer hard questions, they can ask God for wisdom and trust in His purposes.
points: You don’t have to have all the answers—God guides you.
Your own weaknesses become invitation to depend on Him.
In telling your child you do like being a mom, you’re also testifying to God’s goodness in the middle of difficulty.

content.headline: Recognizing Motherhood as a Valued Calling, Not a Lesser Role
content.intro: Many mothers feel pressure to justify their choice to stay at home and raise children, especially in environments that prioritize professional achievements. Embracing the role of motherhood as a proud and meaningful calling highlights its dignity and importance.

sections.title: Feeling Underrepresented
sections.content: Attending professional or social events often highlights accomplishments like job titles, awards, and academic degrees. Introducing oneself as 'just a mom' can feel awkward or undervalued, creating the sense that raising children is a lesser role compared to professional success.

sections.title: Societal Expectations vs. Family Commitment
sections.content: Cultural emphasis on corporate achievements often overshadows the daily labor involved in nurturing a family. Preparing meals, managing household tasks, supporting emotional well-being, and teaching children essential life skills are substantial efforts that shape the next generation but remain largely invisible to society.

sections.title: The Daily Work of Motherhood
sections.content: Motherhood involves countless small yet significant tasks: attending to children's emotional needs, helping with homework, guiding moral and social development, maintaining routines, and ensuring a safe and supportive home environment. Each of these tasks contributes to shaping children into empathetic, capable, and resilient individuals.

sections.title: Emotional Labor and Mental Energy
sections.content: Mothers perform immense emotional work, balancing household dynamics, responding to family needs, managing stress, and often sacrificing personal time. This emotional labor, though invisible, is essential for creating a stable, nurturing environment in which children can thrive.

sections.title: Motherhood as Leadership
sections.content: Raising children requires decision-making, conflict resolution, time management, mentoring, and problem-solving skills. Guiding children through challenges, teaching values, and preparing them for adulthood demonstrates strong leadership qualities and strategic thinking inherent in the role of a mother.

sections.title: Reclaiming Pride in the Role
sections.content: Standing tall and embracing the title of 'mother' affirms the value of this role. Acknowledging the importance of everyday contributions builds self-confidence and sets a positive example for children and other parents, reinforcing the dignity and honor in choosing family over other societal pressures.

sections.title: Impact Beyond the Home
sections.content: Decisions and lessons at home extend into communities and society as a whole. Children raised with care, empathy, and resilience grow into adults who contribute positively to society. This ripple effect underscores the broader impact of committed motherhood.

sections.title: Encouragement and Empowerment
sections.content: Every mother can take pride in her choices, regardless of whether they align with conventional definitions of success. Valuing the role of mother encourages empowerment, validation, and respect, creating a cultural shift toward honoring the contributions of mothers everywhere.

content.headline: Use mindfulness techniques to reduce stress and improve your parenting presence
content.intro: Parenting brings stress, anxieties and constant demands. Applying mindful practices can help reduce reactivity, improve your connection with your children, and create a calmer, more compassionate environment.

sections.title: Bring attention to your own stress
sections.content: Stress in parents is a major contributor to family stress. Recognising when you’re tense, rushed or overwhelmed is an important first step. Studies show parental stress is often the largest source of childhood anxiety. Slowing down and noticing your own inner state helps you respond differently

sections.title: Pause before reacting
sections.content: In emotionally charged moments with children, pause, take a breath, and orient yourself. That moment of awareness before reacting gives your nervous system a chance to shift from auto‑pilot to choice. A calmer parent fosters a safer environment.

sections.title: Engage fully in the moment
sections.content: Put aside distractions—phones, chores, future tasks—and focus on the child in front of you. Giving full attention, even for a few minutes, builds trust and emotional attunement. It signals to your child that they matter.

sections.title: Accept imperfection and practice compassion
sections.content: Parenting is messy and mistakes happen. Rather than judging yourself harshly, adopt a stance of curiosity and kindness. Being gentle with yourself allows you to be gentler with your children.

sections.title: Create mindful routines
sections.content: Small adjustments—such as starting the morning with a breathing moment, or ending the evening with a check‑in with your child—can make the whole day calmer. Slowing ritualises connection rather than chaos.

sections.title: Teach by example
sections.content: Children pick up how parents regulate their emotions. When you model pausing, breathing, tuning in rather than yelling, you’re giving your child a blueprint for self‑regulation, emotional awareness and resilience.
